description:
Most organizations, whether internal-business or software shops, have at least one large, all-encompassing application that represents decades of man-years of effort. Starting off small, targeted and well-intentioned, over time it's become the do-everything solution essential to overall business success. Many dark secrets lurk in the code base - 5K-line methods, magic configuration files, copy-and-pasted code for business rules that is both inconsistent and undocumented, random waits in code to "solve" race conditions, no unit tests - requiring tribal knowledge known to few. You shudder in fear whenever working on the repo.


Leadership eventually realizes they have a problem because of:

  • too many production bugs;
  • too much time spent on maintenance;
  • dramatic increase in time required to deliver new features;
  • reliance on key resources to provide the tribal knowledge needed;
  • tech debt comes up in every engineering planning session.


Organizations - for good reasons - are loathe to accept that a rewrite is the only solution and demand other less-costly solutions. After much analysis, discussions, and deliberations, the technical leads come up with the technical direction: Demonolith the Monolith!


Conceptually simple, but in reality impossible. Really. Join me as I discuss the potential issues/problems that turns this effort into a never-ending, never-completed solution that ultimately requires a rewrite.
title: Demonolithing the Monolith?  Bullocks!
